channel.title: Life on Mars
channel.description:
What do you think? Has there ever been life on mars, or is there still?
MY OPINION. I belive Mars was once like earth. Atmosphere, rivers, mountains. The year would be longer because of its further distance from the sun. I belive something bad happend, eg; Nuclear explosions, natural disasters, OR global warming distroyed the atmospher, wrecking it. It is selfish to think that we are alone in this universe.

item.title: Life on Mars
item.dc:creator: @Hex_Key Hex Key
item.description:
@Hex_Key wrote:

[quote=“XxKanexX, post:27, topic:157075”][quote author=Hex Key link=topic=214205.msg1871525#msg1871525 date=1194362147]

There will be no life until humans go there. And plant trees and such to make a breathable atmosphere.

Total time for it to happen = 10,000 years.

Keep your hopes up. You might just live to be 10,000.

So why are we here, then? Humans don’t need to go places for there to be life.
We came from (scientific theory, saw it on discovery channel) cells, or some shit, from meteors.

That’s also how water came to the planet.
Showers of Meteors hit the planet, fragments of ice water in them… Over time more and more water, eventually creating oceans.
Then some rock in the ocean (forget it’s name- Starts with B) used photosynthesis or something to exchange the iron in the water for oxygen. Bubbles of oxygen floated to the surface, and into the atmosphere.
Over a long period of time earth had oxygen- giving Earth it’s blue, visible sky.

Then life came.

I ain’t saying that’s true, It’s just what I’ve seen; makes sense to me.

you seem to be forgetting that those little bacteria that created our wonderfula atmosphere and made it possible for growth on land and not in the soup are in fact alive! BACTERIA ARE ALIVE.
[/quote]
It probably explained that, i just can’t remember.
Maybe the cells were frozen?

And heated up over time.[/quote]

Checkout my panspermia link a few posts ago, you are talking about panspermia. Infortunately the RNA world hypothesis is sooooo much better and panspermia research to date has been absolutely shit and is ingeneral a shit theory.

Read full topic

item.title: Life on Mars
item.dc:creator: @dragonus18 dragonus18
item.description:
@dragonus18 wrote:

my theory is that humans were created off the DNA of some advanced extraterestrial life forms, VIA bioengineering they took samples of their own DNA and cloned some of it thus, creating us, but we are more primitive and is why we may only use 10% of our brain at most, because some of the other parts might be for things we were never [programmed] to do. to keep us down, so we are not able to devolope as much as other [cultures] have, so they will be in power when they come back to check on us.

item.title: Life on Mars
item.dc:creator: @Hex_Key Hex Key
item.description:
@Hex_Key wrote:

[quote=“Buzzy, post:22, topic:157075”][quote author=.Flair link=topic=214205.msg1869412#msg1869412 date=1194251353]
People are rather close-minded on the subject.
[/quote]

True. Example:

the only life that can live without oxygen is anaerobic bacteria and fungi like yeast.
nothing complex and by complex i mean an animal or plant

Your saying that in a universe that is constantly expanding, and entropy is nothing more than a myth, that there isn’t something out there that would be able to develop in oxygen?

YOUR WRONG[/quote]

in order to defend Bang Train, he did specify “complex” - his definition of complex appears to be multicellular with cellular differentiation. I’d say he is right. No complex organism has developed independently in a non oxygen atmosphere. I am not saying a oxygen requiring specie has not developed pre oxygen atmosphere though, some may have by some form of symbiosis.

Read full topic

item.title: Life on Mars
item.dc:creator: @Hex_Key Hex Key
item.description:
@Hex_Key wrote:

a mod fancy cleaning this once legit topic up of gay porn/ pixies lyrics?

On Topic: silicon doesnt lend its self aswell to forming life, it physical properies are far too constrained, and because evolution is driven by natural selection only the best molecules win. Silicon based molecules fail horrifically all over the shop. but star trek geeks still insist it will work.

Read full topic

item.title: Life on Mars
item.dc:creator: @PaulT PaulT
item.description:
@PaulT wrote:

the only life that can live without oxygen is anaerobic bacteria and fungi like yeast. nothing complex and by complex i mean an animal or plant

The only life that we know of. What human science has discovered is a tiny fraction of what there is to discover. What about silicone based life forms?

item.title: Life on Mars
item.dc:creator: @Bang_Train Bang Train
item.description:
@Bang_Train wrote:

[quote=“Bang Train, post:16, topic:157075”][quote author=OnlyOneRule link=topic=214205.msg1869806#msg1869806 date=1194291782]
Maybe the life on Mars or any other planet doesn’t need to breath oxygen.
[/quote]
complex life would due to its electro negativity it is the best element for the final element in the electron transport chain, with out it life is less efficient

the only life that can live without oxygen is anaerobic bacteria and fungi like yeast.
nothing complex and by complex i mean an animal or plant[/quote]

There are still some really effiecient anaerobic metablosims based on sulphate respiration or DMSO etc e.g. the methanogens.
[/quote]

this is true, but they are still not efficient enough to sustain complex life (like a blue footed booby)

Read full topic

item.title: Life on Mars
item.dc:creator: @Hex_Key Hex Key
item.description:
@Hex_Key wrote:

OnlyOneRule:

Maybe the life on Mars or any other planet doesn’t need to breath oxygen.

Thats a fair point, and if it still alive there today it must be able to live with a near zero dissolved oxygen environment. All the best organisms dont use oxygen as the terminal electron acceptor.[br][size=1]Posted on: November 05, 2007, 08:47:04 AM[/size][hr][quote=“Bang Train, post:16, topic:157075”][quote author=OnlyOneRule link=topic=214205.msg1869806#msg1869806 date=1194291782]
Maybe the life on Mars or any other planet doesn’t need to breath oxygen.
[/quote]
complex life would due to its electro negativity it is the best element for the final element in the electron transport chain, with out it life is less efficient

the only life that can live without oxygen is anaerobic bacteria and fungi like yeast.
nothing complex and by complex i mean an animal or plant[/quote]

There are still some really effiecient anaerobic metablosims based on sulphate respiration or DMSO etc e.g. the methanogens.

Read full topic

item.title: Life on Mars
item.dc:creator: @Hex_Key Hex Key
item.description:
@Hex_Key wrote:

[quote=“Bang Train, post:13, topic:157075”]an oxygen rich atmosphere would kill probably all primitive life (or life trying to form)

its a very electronegative element so it goes RAWR I STEALZ YOUR ELECTRONS!

and the other molecule just falls apart.
the original earth atmosphere had 0 oxygen so the amino acids could form, and not be ripped apart by the oxygen[/quote]

All the Oxygen was locked up in the crust as rust. It wasnt until early iron metabolising oxygenic bacteria started using rust as an electron donator, or terminal electron acceptor that Oxygen appeared in our atmosphere.

Read full topic

item.title: Life on Mars
item.dc:creator: @Bang_Train Bang Train
item.description:

and the other molecule just falls apart.
the original earth atmosphere had 0 oxygen so the amino acids could form, and not be ripped apart by the oxygen

item.title: Life on Mars
item.dc:creator: @Hex_Key Hex Key
item.description:
@Hex_Key wrote:

id be pretty surprised if there wasnt life on mars tbh, water is a excellent indicator of primitive life e.g nanoarchaeota and other archeal families. Whether humans accidentally put it up there or it was seeded in a panspermic way is the real question, then we could work out how we came about and disprove either the RNA world hypothesis or panspermia.

Panspermia: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Panspermia

RNA World Hypothesis: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/RNA_world_hypothesis

^ Some really awesome evolutionary science that will make you look super smart in class + bonus its not difficult or long to read.

Read full topic

item.title: Life on Mars
item.dc:creator: @gothic_queen casey.
item.description:
@gothic_queen wrote:

The sky is the most beautiful thing to look at, I do find myself sitting outside for hours just looking up, and thinking we’re not alone.
I do believe there are other life forms, like .flair said, the universe is huge, there has to be something else out there.

Do I believe in life on Mars?

Who knows, maybe there is something we missed.

Read full topic
